ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Calculus 1- derivatives, antiderivates, ivt, mvt, slope fields, limits, ftc, linearization, curve sketching, optimization, eulers rule
I learned the fundamentals of calculus and how to apply theorems properly.
I learned a lot about calculus with one variable and different problem solving techniques
Helped refresh and build upon my knowledge from AP AB Calc.
Better study habits and how to evaluate integrals

I learned a lot about how to apply the math I have learned my whole life. It was challenging at some points because I was not used to solving problems that had not been explicitly exampled before, but it was a good struggle to use what I had learned.

The insights I primarily developed by taking this course were resourcefulness and using my peers to increase my knowledge and level of retainment for the material. Being my first semester at Yale, I learned a lot by doing this as I had less guidance and help from teachers in this math course than math courses I'd taken previously.
I think i have a good knowledge and foundation of calculus.
Critical/creative thinking in mathematical context.
I have developed some logical thinking skills thanks to the challenging but rewarding psets.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Strengths: The grading is fair. There are many practice exams and past midterms/finals that are available to study for these exams. If you want to get a good grade in the class, just devote some time to studying and doing these and you will be fine.   Weaknesses: The problem sets can sometimes have problems much harder than those shown in class.
Yakov seemed to not know what specific problems he should go over, so some sort of protocol giving suggested problems to go over might be nice for teachers.
office hours were very helpful.  The way my class was run could've been improved.  more checking in with the students to see if they are following
The course moved at a nice pace, could have used more clarification on some topics.
I thought the workload was very manageable and the practice tests for the midterms and finals were helpful.
I think the one big weakness is different professors teach the course very differently.

The strengths of the course are simple: the curriculum is stagnant and easy to see what is necessary to learn. The weaknesses lie in the teaching systems. While I enjoyed my TA as a person, I felt disadvantaged as compared to other students in the course with different TA's as I had trouble understanding them throughout the whole semester, and felt like the teacher was too "smart" and thought the material too trivial to be able to consistently and successfully teach me the material.
More tests and quizzes.
I think depending on the professor you have the course can be very challenging or very easy.
The strength of the class is that you get good support from office hours. Go to them!

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would recommend this course to a student who has either taken calculus ab/1 in high school or is prepared to take some time to really study and learn (sometimes by themselves) the material. If one studies the material a bit outside of class and pays attention in class and to the Ximera's, they should do well. However, I do reccomend that students try to get into a class with a good teacher. The teaching isn't very good overall in the course, which is bad considering the semi-quick speed of the course. In the instance one gets a poor teacher, be prepared to self-study the concepts they didn't understand in class.
Yes because it is helpful to be experienced with mathematics especially if you go into any other STEM fields.
yes - I think it is a solid course to take and opens up a lot of options and is a good QR credit.
Its a requirement, so in that sense, yes.
I would explain this course as it is a good stepping stone requirement into economics and had very helpful teachers and peer tutors.
I would recommend this course because I think the information is valuable.
Yes, its an absolute gut and an easy way to get a QR credit out of the way especially first year first semester.
Yes, as it is the basics necessary to lay a calculus foundation which is important for many different majors and courses in the future at Yale.
Yes
I think this is a good course to take so you can get distributional requirements out of the way.
If you haven never taken calculus before this is the place to start because it assumes its your first interaction with the subject.
Yes it was a good calculus class for my first year
